        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78144",
            "summaryMessage": "Recent app-consistent recovery point not available",
            "errorMessage": "No application consistent recovery point available for the VM in the last 240 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            App consistent recovery point threshold exceeded.\n            1. Issues in the volume shadow copy service (Windows) are causing application consistent snapshot failures.\n            2. Replication is progressing slowly or is not progressing as expected.\n            3. The target storage account is not provisioned with sufficient throughput or IOPs to handle the volume of replication data.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n            Ensure that:\n            1. Application-consistent snapshot frequency is configured to a valid value in the replication policy.\n            2. Check the event logs on the source machine for any VSS failures (Windows)\n            3. Network connectivity exists between the mobility service and the process server.\n            4. Network connectivity exists between the process server and the Azure storage account the machine is replicating to.\n            5. Data upload on the protected machine hasn’t been throttled.\n            6. There is sufficient network bandwidth available between the protected machine and the process server, and the process server and Azure.\n            7. Look for any associated events in the site recovery events table and resolve them if any.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-16T17:04:15.7849621Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks '/dev/sda, /dev/sdb'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-16T14:12:55.7959731Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          },
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78092",

            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-16T14:12:55.7959731Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          },
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78174",
            "summaryMessage": "No Mobility Service heartbeat",
            "errorMessage": "No heartbeat received from the mobility service on the source machine 'prgoyal-ubuntu1404' in the last 15 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            1. The mobility service is not running on the source machine\n            2. There is no network connectivity from the source machine to the configuration server.\n            3. The source machine is not up\n            4. The source machine is running a version of the mobility service older than 9.4 and is unable to authenticate with the configuration server\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          Ensure that\n          1) The source machine is up and that the mobility service(\"InMage Scout VX Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\", and  \"InMage Scout Application Service\") is running on the host\n          2) The source machines has network connectivity to the configuration server on the configuration server tcp port 443.\n          3) If the mobility service version on the machine is 9.3 or lower, upgrade to the latest version of the mobility service\n          Read more at https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-no-heartbeat.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-16T14:12:55.7959731Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks '/dev/sda, /dev/sdb'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-16T14:12:55.7490772Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78144",
            "summaryMessage": "Recent app-consistent recovery point not available",
            "errorMessage": "No application consistent recovery point available for the VM in the last 1830 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            App consistent recovery point threshold exceeded.\n            1. Issues in the volume shadow copy service (Windows) are causing application consistent snapshot failures.\n            2. Replication is progressing slowly or is not progressing as expected.\n            3. The target storage account is not provisioned with sufficient throughput or IOPs to handle the volume of replication data.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n            Ensure that:\n            1. Application-consistent snapshot frequency is configured to a valid value in the replication policy.\n            2. Check the event logs on the source machine for any VSS failures (Windows)\n            3. Network connectivity exists between the mobility service and the process server.\n            4. Network connectivity exists between the process server and the Azure storage account the machine is replicating to.\n            5. Data upload on the protected machine hasn’t been throttled.\n            6. There is sufficient network bandwidth available between the protected machine and the process server, and the process server and Azure.\n            7. Look for any associated events in the site recovery events table and resolve them if any.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-12T12:14:29.1581992Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

            "errorCode": "78143",
            "summaryMessage": "Recent crash consistent recovery point not available",
            "errorMessage": "No crash consistent recovery point available for the VM in the last 60 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            Crash consistent recovery point threshold exceeded.\n            1. Replication is progressing slowly or is not progressing as expected.\n            2. The target storage account is not provisioned with sufficient throughput or IOPs to handle the volume of replication data.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n            Ensure that:\n            1. Network connectivity exists between the mobility service and the process server.\n            2. Data upload on the protected machine hasn’t been throttled.\n            4. There is sufficient network bandwidth available between the protected machine and the process server, and the process server and Azure.\n            5. Look for any associated events in the ASR events table and resolve them if any.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-11T09:09:13.3303799Z",

      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091850224308745648_e591d64f-cc05-40ee-94b6-d1020b9576c6",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Warning state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "V2APS3",
        "severity": "Warning",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-10-11T07:40:54.6030159Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3.           {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-11T07:40:54.5561384Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]

The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-11T06:18:20.6864264Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-11T05:12:19.9702735Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-11T04:22:43.2202141Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-11T03:16:44.9139105Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091850432367868173_7d4f336e-d5bf-40ad-b504-0c3eee68122a",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Warning state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "V2APS2",
        "severity": "Warning",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-10-11T01:54:08.6907634Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-11T01:54:08.6907634Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-11T01:21:06.8010084Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",

      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091850501749057672_20590355-a715-455b-9f53-d14b04fda579",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Warning state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "V2APS3",
        "severity": "Warning",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-10-10T23:58:30.5718135Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T23:58:30.5718135Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

        "eventCode": "InMageCommon_ECH0007",
        "description": "RPO threshold exceeded.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "V2APS5",
        "severity": "Warning",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-10-10T23:25:29.80449Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T23:25:29.80449Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T22:52:27.1114281Z",

      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "EA0431",
        "description": "App-consistent recovery point tagging failed.",
        "eventType": "AgentHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "ScaleWinSrc14",
        "severity": "OK",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-10-10T21:23:58Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/95052ac8502db27cd7f8cd7a5ecd957d67a29d110d6becc190f6dda01579e772",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": "Agent health",
          "category": "Agent Has Logged Alerts",
          "component": "Agent",
          "correctiveAction": "This may be a transient failure. Repeated and multiple app-consistent tag generation failures on a replicating machine may be indicative of other issues, such as VSS snapshot failures on Windows due to multiple VSS applications issuing snapshot requests.",
          "details": "Allication consistency command failed. Policy Id : 34Command issued: \\\"C:\\\\Program Files (x86)\\\\Microsoft Azure Site Recovery\\\\agent\\\\vacp.exe\\\" -systemlevel  -hydration \\\"_no_hydration:_azure;_desc:atapi=0,dhcp=2,intelide=0,storflt=0,storvsc=0,vmbus=0\\\" Failed nodes: (SCALEWINSRC14,10.150.2.178,VACP_E_DRIVER_IN_NON_DATA_MODE [10003])\\n on SCALEWINSRC14(10.150.2.178)",
          "summary": "App-consistent recovery point tagging failed.",
          "siteName": "ScaleWinSrc22"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "90075",
            "summaryMessage": "",
            "errorMessage": "App-consistent recovery tag generation for (SCALEWINSRC14,10.150.2.178,VACP_E_DRIVER_IN_NON_DATA_MODE [10003]) has failed.",
            "possibleCauses": "App-consistent recovery point tagging failed.",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        This may be a transient failure. Azure Site Recovery will attempt generating an application consistent recovery point again in the next cycle. Check the latest application-consistent recovery point available for this replicated item from the Azure portal. If the latest available application consistent recovery point is very old and you are seeing repeated and multiple app-consistent tag generation failures on a replicating machine, this may be indicative of other issues, such as:\n        1. VSS snapshot failures on Windows due to multiple VSS applications issuing snapshot requests. Check the VSS logs in event viewer on the source machine and fix any errors.\n        2. Insufficient bandwidth to upload replication data either between the source machine and the process server, or the process server and the Azure storage account you are replicating to.Ensure you are replicating to the approproiate storage account tier based on the data change rate (churn) on the source machine and that the data change rate is within Azure Site Recovery supported limits for the storage tier you are replicating to.\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T21:23:58Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091850611013927930_f0568ba8-6098-4e5d-ac72-ec2d96583f68",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Warning state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "V2APS5",
        "severity": "Warning",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-10-10T20:56:24.0847877Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T20:56:24.0847877Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T20:39:51.0481166Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

    {
      "name": "VmMonitoringEvent;9091850650631424094_0cebb82f-1fcb-4177-8cf2-9e680757ca46",
      "type": "Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/replicationEvents",
      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091850650631424094_0cebb82f-1fcb-4177-8cf2-9e680757ca46",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "InMageCommon_ECH0007",
        "description": "RPO threshold exceeded.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "NS-WIN-SRC3",
        "severity": "Warning",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-10-10T19:50:22.3351713Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T19:50:22.3351713Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T19:17:18.8889148Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T17:54:15.6069532Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T17:21:18.4552066Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

    {
      "name": "VmMonitoringEvent;9091850779725731153_d71f4f72-9192-4c28-910d-a38a0e8108d3",
      "type": "Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/replicationEvents",
      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091850779725731153_d71f4f72-9192-4c28-910d-a38a0e8108d3",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Warning state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "V2APS2",
        "severity": "Warning",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-10-10T16:15:12.9044654Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T16:15:12.9044654Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

      "type": "Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/replicationEvents",
      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091850819372429489_f11e8dc8-7ca0-4f94-800b-c9698aa29ce2",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Warning state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "V2APS5",
        "severity": "Warning",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-10-10T15:09:08.2346318Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/9a72155b61d09325a02ba0311dea55df3a7135b65558b43c9ff540b9e7be084f",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "summaryMessage": "RPO threshold exceeded",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-10-10T15:09:08.2346318Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

      "name": "VmMonitoringEvent;9091850858995000112_d0634169-4954-4251-acc5-9802871d97e9",
